"[108-the girl who had passed the yorkshire relish] [She]108-the girl who had passed the yorkshire relish walked past the English table , and the Polish table , and so out of [the Kurhaus dining - hall]113-the kurhaus dining - hall . IN [an old second - hand bookshop in [London]3-london]114-an old second - hand bookshop in london , [an old man]115-an old man sat reading [Gibbon]29-gibbon 's History of [Rome]4-rome . [He]115-an old man did not put down [his]115-an old man book when [the postman]116-the postman brought [him]115-an old man a letter . [He]115-an old man just glanced indifferently at the letter , and impatiently at [the postman]116-the postman . [Zerviah Holme]30-zerviah holme did not like to be interrupted when [he]30-zerviah holme was reading [Gibbon]29-gibbon ; and as [he]30-zerviah holme was always reading [Gibbon]29-gibbon , an interruption was always regarded by [him]30-zerviah holme as an insult . About two hours afterwards , [he]30-zerviah holme opened the letter , and learnt that [[his]30-zerviah holme niece]118-his niece , [Bernardine]31-bernardine , had arrived safely in [Petershof]2-petershof , and that [she]118-his niece intended to get better and come [home]119-home strong . [He]30-zerviah holme tore up the letter , and instinctively turned to the photograph on the mantelpiece . It was the picture of a face young and yet old , sad and yet with possibilities of merriment , thin and drawn and almost wrinkled , and with piercing eyes which , even in the dull lifelessness of the photograph , seemed to be burning themselves away . Not a pleasing nor a good face ; yet intensely pathetic because of its undisguised harassment . [Zerviah]30-zerviah holme looked at it for a moment . " [She]118-his niece has never been much to either of [us]942-us , "[30-zerviah holme] [he]30-zerviah holme said to [himself]30-zerviah holme . " And yet , when [Malvina]32-malvina was alive , [I]30-zerviah holme used to think that [she]118-his niece was hard on [Bernardine]31-bernardine . [I]30-zerviah holme believe [I]30-zerviah holme said so once or twice . But [Malvina]32-malvina had [her]32-malvina own way of looking at things . Well , that is over now . "[30-zerviah holme] [He]30-zerviah holme then , with characteristic speed , dismissed all thoughts which did not relate to Roman History ; and the remembrance of [Malvina]32-malvina , [[his]30-zerviah holme wife]120-his wife , and [Bernardine]31-bernardine , [[his]30-zerviah holme niece]118-his niece , took up an accustomed position in the background of [his]30-zerviah holme mind . [Bernardine]31-bernardine had suffered a cheerless childhood in which dolls and toys took no leading part . [She]31-bernardine had no affection to bestow on any doll , nor any woolly lamb , nor apparently on [any human person]122-any human person ; unless , perhaps , there was the possibility of a friendly inclination towards [Uncle Zerviah]33-zerviah , who would not have understood the value of any deeper feeling , and did not therefore call [the child]123-the child cold - hearted and unresponsive , as [he]33-zerviah might well have done . This [she]31-bernardine certainly was , judged by the standard of [other children]124-other children ; but then no softening influences had been at work during [her]31-bernardine tenderest years . [Aunt Malvina]32-malvina knew as much about sympathy as [she]32-malvina did about the properties of an ellipse ; and even [the fairies]125-the fairies had failed to win [little Bernardine]31-bernardine . At first [they]125-the fairies tried with loving patience what [they]125-the fairies might do for [her]31-bernardine ; [they]125-the fairies came out of [their]125-the fairies books , and danced and sang to [her]31-bernardine , and whispered sweet stories to [her]31-bernardine , at twilight , [the fairies]125-the fairies ' own time . But [she]31-bernardine would have none of [them]125-the fairies , for all [their]125-the fairies gentle persuasion . So [they]125-the fairies gave up trying to please [her]31-bernardine , and left [her]31-bernardine as [they]125-the fairies had found [her]31-bernardine , loveless . What can be said of a childhood which even [the fairies]125-the fairies have failed to touch with the warm glow of affection ? Such a little restless spirit , striving to express itself now in this direction , now in that ; yet always actuated by the same constant force , the desire for work . [Bernardine]31-bernardine seemed to have no special wish to be useful to [others]939-others ; [she]31-bernardine seemed just to have a natural tendency to work , even as [others]939-others have a natural tendency to play . [She]31-bernardine was always in earnest ; life for [little Bernardine]31-bernardine meant something serious . Then the years went by . [She]31-bernardine grew up and filled [her]31-bernardine life with many interests and ambitions . [She]31-bernardine was at least [a worker]130-a worker , if nothing else ; [she]31-bernardine had always been [a diligent scholar]131-a diligent scholar , and now [she]31-bernardine took [her]31-bernardine place as [an able teacher]132-an able teacher . [She]31-bernardine was self - reliant , and , perhaps , somewhat conceited . But , at least , [Bernardine]31-bernardine [the young woman]133-the young woman had learnt something which [Bernardine]31-bernardine [the young child]134-the young child had not been able to learn : [she]31-bernardine learnt how to smile . It took [her]31-bernardine , about six and twenty years to learn ; still , [some people]135-some people take longer than that ; in fact , [many]136-many never learn . This is a brief summary of [Bernardine Holme]31-bernardine 's past . Then , one day , when [she]31-bernardine was in the full swing of [her]31-bernardine many engrossing occupations : teaching , writing articles for newspapers , attending socialistic meetings , and taking part in political discussions — [she]31-bernardine was essentially [a modern product]137-a modern product , this [Bernardine]31-bernardine — one day [she]31-bernardine fell ill . [She]31-bernardine lingered in [London]3-london for some time , and then [she]31-bernardine went to [Petershof]2-petershof . [PETERSHOF]2-petershof was [a winter resort for [consumptive patients]139-consumptive patients]138-a winter resort for consumptive patients , though , indeed , [many people]140-many people simply needed the change of a bracing climate went [there]141-there to spend a few months ; and came , away wonderfully better for the mountain air . This was what [Bernardine Holme]31-bernardine hoped to do ; [she]31-bernardine was broken down in every way , but it was thought that a prolonged stay in [Petershof]2-petershof might help [her]31-bernardine back to a reasonable amount of health , or , at least , prevent [her]31-bernardine from slipping into further decline . [She]31-bernardine had come alone , because [she]31-bernardine had no relations except [that old uncle]142-that old uncle , and no money to pay [any friend who might have been willing to come with [her]31-bernardine]143-any friend who might have been willing to come with her . But [she]31-bernardine probably cared very little , and the morning after [her]31-bernardine arrival , [she]31-bernardine strolled out by [herself]31-bernardine , investigating [the place where [she]31-bernardine was about to spend six months]144-the place where she was about to spend six months . [She]31-bernardine was dragging [herself]31-bernardine along , when [she]31-bernardine met [the Disagreeable Man]102-the disagreeable man . [She]31-bernardine stopped [him]102-the disagreeable man . [He]102-the disagreeable man was not accustomed to be stopped by [any one]146-any one , and [he]102-the disagreeable man looked rather astonished . "[147-she] " [You]147-she are not the only one who has had to do that , "[148-he] [he]148-he said sharply . " Why make a fuss ? Things arrange themselves , and eventually [we]949-we adjust [ourselves]949-we to the new arrangement . A great deal of caring and grieving , phase one ; still more caring and grieving , phase two ; less caring and grieving , phase three ; no further feeling whatsoever , phase four . Mercifully [I]148-he am at phase four . [You]147-she are at phase one . Make a quick journey over the stages . "[148-he] [He]148-he turned and left [her]147-she , and [she]147-she strolled along , thinking of [his]148-he words , wondering how long it would take [her]147-she to arrive at [his]148-he indifference . [She]147-she had always looked upon indifference as paralysis of the soul , and paralysis meant death , nay , was worse than death . And here was [this man , who had obviously suffered both mentally and physically , telling [her]147-she that the only sensible course was to learn not to care]149-this man , who had obviously suffered both mentally and physically , telling her that the only sensible course was to learn not to care . How could [she]147-she learn not to care ? All [her]147-she life long [she]147-she had studied and worked and cultivated [herself]147-she in every direction in the hope of being able to take a high place in literature , or , in any case , to do something in life distinctly better than what [other people]150-other people did . When everything was coming near to [her]147-she grasp , when there seemed a fair chance of realizing [her]147-she ambitions , [she]147-she had suddenly fallen ill , broken up so entirely in every way , that [those who knew [her]147-she when [she]147-she was well]151-those who knew her when she was well , could scarcely recognize [her]147-she now that [she]147-she was ill . [The doctors]152-the doctors spoke of [an overstrained nervous system]153-an overstrained nervous system : the pestilence of these modern days ; [they]152-the doctors spoke of rest , change of work and scene , bracing air . [She]147-she might regain [her]147-she vitality ; [she]147-she might not . [Those who had played [themselves]154-those who had played themselves out out]154-those who had played themselves out must pay the penalty . [She]147-she was thinking of [her]147-she whole history , pitying [herself]147-she profoundly , coming to the conclusion , after true human fashion , that [she]147-she was [the worst - used person on [earth]156-earth]155-the worst - used person on earth , and that [no one]157-no one but [herself]147-she knew what disappointed ambitions were ; [she]147-she was thinking of all this , and looking profoundly miserable and martyr - like , when [some one]158-some one called [her]147-she by [her]147-she name . "[170-one of the men] " Oh , [I]27-mrs. reffold can easily snub [any one]146-any one if [I]27-mrs. reffold wish , "[27-mrs. reffold] replied [Mrs. Reffold]27-mrs. reffold , rather disdainfully . [He]37-wäli was [a linguist]192-a linguist , too , was Wäli , and could speak broken English in a most fascinating way , agreeable to every one , but intelligible only to [himself]37-wäli . Well , [he]37-wäli came whistling up [the stairs]193-the stairs when [he]37-wäli heard [Marie]39-marie 's blithe voice humming [her]39-marie favourite spinning - song . " Ei , Ei ! And [the Disagreeable Man]28-the disagreeable man went [his]28-the disagreeable man own solitary way , a forlorn figure , with a face almost expressionless , and a manner wholly impenetrable . [He]28-the disagreeable man had lived nearly seven years at [Petershof]2-petershof , and , like [many others]205-many others was obliged to continue staying [there]141-there if [he]28-the disagreeable man wished to continue staying in [this planet]207-this planet . It was not probable that [he]28-the disagreeable man had any wish to prolong [his]28-the disagreeable man frail existence , but [he]28-the disagreeable man did [his]28-the disagreeable man duty to [[his]28-the disagreeable man mother]208-his mother by conserving [his]28-the disagreeable man life ; and this feeble flame of duty and affection was the only lingering bit of warmth in a heart frozen almost by ill health and disappointed ambitions . [The moralists]209-the moralists tell [us]210-us that suffering ennobles , and that a right acceptation of hindrances goes towards forming a beautiful character . But this result must largely depend on [the original character]211-the original character : certainly , in the case of [Robert Allitsen]40-robert allitsen , suffering had not ennobled [his]28-the disagreeable man mind , nor disappointment sweetened [his]28-the disagreeable man disposition . [His]28-the disagreeable man title of " Disagreeable Man "[211-the original character] had been fairly earned , and [he]28-the disagreeable man hugged it to [himself]28-the disagreeable man with a triumphant secret satisfaction . There were [some people in [Petershof]2-petershof]212-some people in petershof who were inclined to believe certain absurd rumours about [his]28-the disagreeable man alleged kindness . It was said that on more than one occasion [he]28-the disagreeable man had nursed the suffering and the dying in [sad Petershof]2-petershof , and , with all the sorrowful tenderness worthy of [a loving mother]213-a loving mother , had helped [them]212-some people in petershof to take [their]212-some people in petershof leave of life . But these were only rumours , and there was nothing in [Robert Allitsen]40-robert allitsen 's ordinary bearing to justify such talk . So [the foolish people who , for the sake of making [themselves]214-the foolish people who , for the sake of making themselves peculiar , revived these unlikely fictions peculiar , revived these unlikely fictions]214-the foolish people who , for the sake of making themselves peculiar , revived these unlikely fictions , were speedily ridiculed and reduced to silence . And [the Disagreeable Man]28-the disagreeable man remained [the Disagreeable Man]102-the disagreeable man , with a clean record for unamiability . [He]28-the disagreeable man lived a life apart from [others]939-others . Most of [his]28-the disagreeable man time was occupied in photography , or in the use and study of the microscope , or in chemistry . [His]28-the disagreeable man photographs were considered to be most beautiful . Not that [he]28-the disagreeable man showed them specially to [any one]146-any one ; but [he]28-the disagreeable man generally sent a specimen of [his]28-the disagreeable man work to the Monthly Photograph Portfolio , and hence it was that [people]946-people learned to know of [his]28-the disagreeable man skill . [He]28-the disagreeable man might be seen any fine day trudging along in company with [his]28-the disagreeable man photographic apparatus , and a desolate dog , who looked almost as cheerless as [[his]28-the disagreeable man chosen comrade]219-his chosen comrade . Neither [the one]220-the one took any notice of [the other]166-the other ; [Allitsen]40-robert allitsen was no more genial to the dog than [he]40-robert allitsen was to [the Kurhaus guests]222-the kurhaus guests ; the dog was no more demonstrative to [Robert Allitsen]40-robert allitsen than [he]28-the disagreeable man was to [any one in [Petershof]2-petershof]223-any one in petershof . Still , [they]224-they were " something "[167-each other] to [each other]167-each other , that unexplainable " something "[167-each other] which has to explain almost every kind of attachment . [He]40-robert allitsen had [no friends]226-no friends in [Petershof]2-petershof , and apparently had [no friends]226-no friends anywhere . [No one]157-no one wrote to [him]40-robert allitsen , except [[his]40-robert allitsen old mother]229-his old mother ; the papers which were sent to [him]40-robert allitsen came from [a stationer]230-a stationer 's . [He]40-robert allitsen read all during meal - time . But now and again [he]40-robert allitsen spoke a few words with [Bernardine Holme]31-bernardine , whose place was next to [him]40-robert allitsen . It never occurred to [him]40-robert allitsen to say good morning , nor to give a greeting of any kind , nor to show a courtesy . One day during lunch , however , [he]40-robert allitsen did take the trouble to stoop and pick up [Bernardine Holme]31-bernardine 's shawl , which had fallen for the third time to the ground . " [I]40-robert allitsen never saw [a female]999-a female wear a shawl more carelessly than [you]31-bernardine , "[40-robert allitsen] [he]40-robert allitsen said . " [You]31-bernardine do n't seem to know anything about it . "[40-robert allitsen] [His]40-robert allitsen manner was always gruff . [Every one]231-every one complained of [him]40-robert allitsen . [Every one]231-every one always had complained of [him]40-robert allitsen . [He]40-robert allitsen had never been heard to laugh . Once or twice [he]40-robert allitsen had been seen to smile on occasions when [people]946-people talked confidently of recovering [their]946-people health . It was a beautiful smile worthy of a better cause . It was a smile which made one pause to wonder what could have been the original disposition of [the Disagreeable Man]102-the disagreeable man before ill - health had cut [him]40-robert allitsen off from the affairs of active life . Was [he]40-robert allitsen happy or unhappy ? It was not known . [He]40-robert allitsen gave no sign of either the one state or the other . [He]40-robert allitsen always looked very ill , but [he]40-robert allitsen did not seem to get worse . [He]40-robert allitsen had never been known to make the faintest allusion to [his]40-robert allitsen own health . [He]40-robert allitsen never " smoked "[40-robert allitsen] [his]40-robert allitsen thermometer in public ; and this was the more remarkable in [an hotel]235-an hotel where [people]946-people would even leave off a conversation and say : " Excuse [me]946-people , [Sir]1000-sir or [Madam]1001-madam , [I]946-people must now take [my]946-people temperature . [We]1002-we will resume the topic in a few minutes . "[946-people] [He]40-robert allitsen never lent any papers or books , and [he]40-robert allitsen never borrowed any . [He]40-robert allitsen had [a room at [the top of [the hotel]239-the hotel]238-the top of the hotel]237-a room at the top of the hotel , and [he]40-robert allitsen lived [his]40-robert allitsen life , amongst [his]40-robert allitsen chemistry bottles , [his]40-robert allitsen scientific books , [his]40-robert allitsen microscope , and [his]40-robert allitsen camera . [He]40-robert allitsen never sat in [any of [the hotel drawing - rooms]241-the hotel drawing - rooms]240-any of the hotel drawing - rooms . There was nothing striking nor eccentric about [his]40-robert allitsen appearance . [He]40-robert allitsen was neither ugly nor good - looking , neither tall nor short , neither fair nor dark . [He]40-robert allitsen was thin and frail , and rather bent . But that might be the description of [any one in [Petershof]2-petershof]223-any one in petershof . There was nothing pathetic about [him]40-robert allitsen , no suggestion even of poetry , which gives a reverence to suffering , whether mental or physical . As there was no expression on [his]40-robert allitsen face , so also there was no expression in [his]40-robert allitsen eyes : no distant longing , no far - off fixedness ; nothing , indeed , to awaken sad sympathy . The only positive thing about [him]40-robert allitsen was [his]40-robert allitsen rudeness . Was it natural or cultivated ? [No one in]243-no one in [Petershof]2-petershof could say . [He]40-robert allitsen had always been as [he]40-robert allitsen was ; and there was no reason to suppose that [he]40-robert allitsen would ever be different . [He]40-robert allitsen was , in fact , like the glacier of which [he]40-robert allitsen had such a fine view from [[his]40-robert allitsen room]244-his room ; like [the glacier]245-the glacier , an unchanging feature of [the neighbourhood]246-the neighbourhood . [No one]157-no one loved it better than [the Disagreeable Man]102-the disagreeable man did ; [he]40-robert allitsen watched the sunlight on [it]249-it , now pale golden , now fiery red . [He]40-robert allitsen loved the sky , the dull grey , or the bright blue . [He]40-robert allitsen loved [the snow forests]250-the snow forests , and [the snow - girt streams]251-the snow - girt streams , and the ice cathedrals , and the great firs patient beneath [their]252-their snow - burden . [He]40-robert allitsen loved [the frozen waterfalls]253-the frozen waterfalls , and the costly diamonds in the snow . [He]40-robert allitsen knew , too , where the flowers nestled in their white nursery . [He]40-robert allitsen was , indeed , [an authority on Alpine botany]254-an authority on alpine botany . The same tender hands which plucked the flowers in the spring - time , dissected them and laid them bare beneath the microscope . But [he]40-robert allitsen did not love them the less for that . Were these pursuits a comfort to [him]40-robert allitsen ? Did [they]255-they help [him]40-robert allitsen to forget that there was a time when [he]40-robert allitsen , too , was burning with ambition to distinguish [himself]40-robert allitsen , and be [one of [the marked men of the age]257-the marked men of the age]256-one of the marked men of the age ? Who could say ? COUNTLESS ages ago [a Traveller , much worn with journeying]258-a traveller , much worn with journeying , climbed up [the last bit of rough road]259-the last bit of rough road which led to [the summit of [a high mountain]261-a high mountain]260-the summit of a high mountain . There was [a temple on [that mountain]263-that mountain]262-a temple on that mountain . And [the Traveller]264-the traveller had vowed that [he]264-the traveller would reach [it]263-that mountain before death prevented [him]264-the traveller . [He]264-the traveller knew the journey was long , and [the road]181-the road rough . [He]264-the traveller knew that [the mountain]266-the mountain was the most difficult of ascent of [that mountain chain]267-that mountain chain , called " [The Ideals]9-the ideals . "[264-the traveller] But [he]264-the traveller had a strongly - hoping heart and a sure foot . [He]264-the traveller lost all sense of time , but [he]264-the traveller never lost the feeling of hope . " Even if [I]264-the traveller faint by the way - side , "[264-the traveller] [he]264-the traveller said to [himself]264-the traveller , " and [am]264-the traveller not able to reach [the summit]1003-the summit , still it is something to be on [the road which leads to [the High Ideals]1005-the high ideals]1004-the road which leads to the high ideals . "[264-the traveller] That was how [he]264-the traveller comforted [himself]264-the traveller when [he]264-the traveller was weary . [He]264-the traveller never lost more hope than that ; and surely that was little enough . And now [he]264-the traveller had reached [the temple]268-the temple . [He]264-the traveller rang the bell , and [an old white - haired man]269-an old white - haired man opened the gate . [He]269-an old white - haired man smiled sadly when [he]269-an old white - haired man saw [the Traveller]264-the traveller . " And yet another one , "[269-an old white - haired man] [he]269-an old white - haired man murmured . " What does it all mean ? "[269-an old white - haired man] [The Traveller]264-the traveller did not hear what [he]269-an old white - haired man murmured . " [Old white - haired man]1006-old white - haired man , "[264-the traveller] [he]264-the traveller said , " tell [me]264-the traveller ; and so [I]264-the traveller have come at last to [the wonderful Temple of Knowledge]1007-the wonderful temple of knowledge . [I]264-the traveller have been journeying hither all [my]264-the traveller life . Ah , but it is hard work climbing up to the Ideals . "[264-the traveller] [The old man]272-the old man touched [the Traveller]264-the traveller on the arm . " Listen , "[272-the old man] [he]272-the old man said gently . " This is not [the Temple of Knowledge]1008-the temple of knowledge . And [the Ideals]9-the ideals are not [a chain of mountains]1009-a chain of mountains ; they are [a stretch of plains]1010-a stretch of plains , and [the Temple of Knowledge]1008-the temple of knowledge is in [their]9-the ideals centre . [You]264-the traveller have come [the wrong road]1012-the wrong road . Alas , poor [Traveller]42-traveller ! "[272-the old man] The light in [the Traveller]42-traveller 's eyes had faded . The hope in [his]42-traveller heart died . And [he]42-traveller became old and withered . [He]42-traveller leaned heavily on [his]42-traveller staff . " Can one rest here ? "[42-traveller] [he]42-traveller asked wearily . " No . "[42-traveller] " Is there a way down [the other side of [these mountains]1014-these mountains]1013-the other side of these mountains ? "[264-the traveller] " No . "[264-the traveller] " What are [these mountains]1014-these mountains called ? "[42-traveller] " [They]1014-these mountains have no name . "[264-the traveller] " And [the temple]268-the temple — how do [you]275-the old white - haired man call [the temple]268-the temple ? "[264-the traveller] " [It]268-the temple has no name ! "[42-traveller] " Then [I]264-the traveller call it [the Temple of Broken Hearts]1018-the temple of broken hearts , "[264-the traveller] said [the Traveller]264-the traveller . And [he]264-the traveller turned and went . But [the old white - haired man]275-the old white - haired man followed [him]264-the traveller . " [Brother]43-brother , "[275-the old white - haired man] [he]275-the old white - haired man said , " [you]43-brother are not the first to come here , but [you]43-brother may be the last . Go back to [the plains]1019-the plains , and tell [the dwellers in [the plains]1019-the plains]1020-the dwellers in the plains that [the Temple of True Knowledge]1022-the temple of true knowledge is in [their]1020-the dwellers in the plains very midst ; [any one]146-any one may enter it who chooses , the gate is not even closed . [The Temple]268-the temple has always been in [the plains]1019-the plains , in the very heart of life , and work , and daily effort . [The philosopher]1026-the philosopher may enter , [the stone - breaker]1027-the stone - breaker may enter . [You]43-brother must have passed it every day of [your]43-brother life ; [a plain , venerable building , unlike [[your]43-brother glorious cathedrals]1029-your glorious cathedrals]1028-a plain , venerable building , unlike your glorious cathedrals . "[275-the old white - haired man] " [I]264-the traveller have seen [the children]1030-the children playing near [it]1022-the temple of true knowledge , "[264-the traveller] said [the Traveller]264-the traveller . " When [I]264-the traveller was [a child]1031-a child [I]264-the traveller used to play [there]141-there . Ah , if [I]264-the traveller had only known ! Well , the past is the past . "[264-the traveller] [He]264-the traveller would have rested against a huge stone , but that [the old white - haired man]275-the old white - haired man prevented [him]264-the traveller . " Do not rest , "[275-the old white - haired man] [he]275-the old white - haired man said . " If [you]43-brother once rest there , [you]43-brother will not rise again . When [you]43-brother once rest , [you]43-brother will know how weary [you]43-brother are . "[275-the old white - haired man] " [I]264-the traveller have no wish to go farther , "[264-the traveller] said [the Traveller]264-the traveller . " [My]264-the traveller journey is done ; it may have been in the wrong direction , but still it is done . "[264-the traveller] " Nay , do not linger here , "[272-the old man] urged [the old man]272-the old man . " Retrace [your]43-brother steps . Though [you]43-brother are broken - hearted [yourself]43-brother , [you]43-brother may save [others]939-others from breaking [their]939-others hearts . [Those whom [you]43-brother meet on [this road]1035-this road]1034-those whom you meet on this road , [you]43-brother can turn back . Those who are but starting in this direction [you]43-brother can bid pause and consider how mad it is to suppose that [the Temple of True Knowledge]1022-the temple of true knowledge should have been built on [an isolated and dangerous mountain]1037-an isolated and dangerous mountain . Tell [them]1034-those whom you meet on this road that although [God]44-god seems hard , [He]44-god is not as hard as all that . Tell [them]1034-those whom you meet on this road that [the Ideals]9-the ideals are not [a mountain range]1038-a mountain range , but [[their]9-the ideals own plains]1039-their own plains , where [[their]9-the ideals great cities]1040-their great cities are built , and [where the corn grows]1041-where the corn grows , and where [men]168-men and [women]1043-women are toiling , sometimes in sorrow and sometimes in joy . "[272-the old man] " [I]264-the traveller will go , "[264-the traveller] said [the Traveller]264-the traveller . And [he]264-the traveller started . But [he]264-the traveller had grown old and weary . And the journey was long ; and the retracing of one 's steps is more toilsome than the tracing of [them]281-them . The ascent , with all the vigour and hope of life to help [him]264-the traveller , had been difficult enough ; the descent , with no vigour and no hope to help [him]264-the traveller , was almost impossible . So that it was not probable that [the Traveller]264-the traveller lived to reach [the plains]1019-the plains . But whether [he]264-the traveller reached [them]1019-the plains or not , still [he]264-the traveller had started . And [not many Travellers]284-not many travellers do that . THE crisp mountain air and the warm sunshine began slowly to have their effect on [Bernardine]31-bernardine , in spite of [the Disagreeable Man]28-the disagreeable man 's verdict . [She]31-bernardine still looked singularly lifeless , and appeared to drag [herself]31-bernardine about with painful effort ; but [the place]944-the place suited [her]31-bernardine , and [she]31-bernardine enjoyed sitting in the sun listening to the music which was played by a scratchy string band . [Some of [the Kurhaus guests]222-the kurhaus guests]286-some of the kurhaus guests , seeing that [she]31-bernardine was alone and ailing , made some attempts to be kindly to [her]31-bernardine . [She]31-bernardine always seemed astonished that [people]946-people should concern [themselves]946-people about [her]31-bernardine ; whatever [her]31-bernardine faults were , it never struck [her]31-bernardine that [she]31-bernardine might be of any importance to [others]939-others , however important [she]31-bernardine might be to [herself]31-bernardine . [She]31-bernardine was grateful for any little kindness which was shewn [her]31-bernardine ; but at first [she]31-bernardine kept very much to [herself]31-bernardine , talking chiefly with [the Disagreeable Man , who , by the way , had surprised [every one]231-every one — but [no one]157-no one more than [himself]28-the disagreeable man — by [his]28-the disagreeable man unwonted behaviour in bestowing even a fraction of [his]28-the disagreeable man companionship]28-the disagreeable man on [a Petershof human being]292-a petershof human being . There was a great deal of curiosity about [her]31-bernardine , but [no one]157-no one ventured to question [her]31-bernardine since [Mrs. Reffold]27-mrs. reffold 's defeat . [Mrs. Reffold]27-mrs. reffold [herself]27-mrs. reffold rather avoided [her]31-bernardine , having always a vague suspicion that [Bernardine]31-bernardine tried to make fun of [her]31-bernardine . But whether out of perversity or not , [Bernardine]31-bernardine never would be avoided by [her]31-bernardine , never let [her]31-bernardine pass by without a few words of conversation , and always went to [her]31-bernardine for information , much to the amusement of [[Mrs. Reffold]27-mrs. reffold 's faithful attendants]294-mrs. reffold 's faithful attendants . There was always a twinkle in [Bernardine]31-bernardine 's eye when [she]31-bernardine spoke with [Mrs. Reffold]27-mrs. reffold . [She]31-bernardine never fastened [herself]31-bernardine on to [any one]146-any one ; [no one]157-no one could say [she]31-bernardine intruded . As time went , on there was a vague sort of feeling that [she]31-bernardine did not intrude enough . [She]31-bernardine was ready to speak if [any one]146-any one cared to speak with [her]31-bernardine , but [she]31-bernardine never began a conversation except with [Mrs. Reffold]27-mrs. reffold . When [people]946-people did talk to [her]31-bernardine , [they]946-people found [her]31-bernardine genial . Then the sad face would smile kindly , and the sad eyes speak kind sympathy . Or some bit of fun would flash forth , and a peal of young laughter ring out . It seemed strange that such fun could come from [her]31-bernardine . [Those who noticed [her]31-bernardine]299-those who noticed her , said [she]31-bernardine appeared always to be thinking . [She]31-bernardine was thinking and learning . Some few remarks roughly made by [the Disagreeable Man]102-the disagreeable man had impressed [her]31-bernardine deeply . " [You]31-bernardine have come to [a new world]1044-a new world , "[102-the disagreeable man] [he]102-the disagreeable man said , " [the world of suffering]1045-the world of suffering . [You]31-bernardine are in a fury because [your]31-bernardine career has been checked , and because [you]31-bernardine have been put on the shelf ; [you]31-bernardine , of [all people]1046-all people . Now [you]31-bernardine will learn how many quite as able as [yourself]31-bernardine , and abler , have been put on the shelf too , and have to stay there . [You]31-bernardine are only [a pupil in suffering]1047-a pupil in suffering . What about [the professors]1048-the professors ? If [your]31-bernardine wonderful wisdom has left [you]31-bernardine with any sense at all , look about [you]31-bernardine and learn . "[102-the disagreeable man] So [she]31-bernardine was looking , and thinking , and learning . And as the days went by , perhaps a softer light came into [her]31-bernardine eyes . All [her]31-bernardine life long , [her]31-bernardine standard of [judging people]301-judging people had been an intellectual standard , or an artistic standard : what [people]946-people had done with outward and visible signs ; how far [they]946-people had contributed to thought ; how far [they]946-people had influenced any great movement , or originated it ; how much of a benefit [they]946-people had been to [their]946-people century or [[their]946-people country]303-their country ; how much social or political activity , how much educational energy [they]946-people had devoted to the pressing need of the times . [She]31-bernardine was undoubtedly [a clever , cultured young woman]304-a clever , cultured young woman ; the great work of [her]31-bernardine life had been self - culture . To know and understand , [she]31-bernardine had spared neither [herself]31-bernardine nor [any one else]995-any one else . To know , and to use [her]31-bernardine acquired knowledge intellectually as [teacher]306-teacher and , perhaps , too , as [writer]307-writer , had been the great aim of [her]31-bernardine life . Everything that furthered this aim won [her]31-bernardine instant attention . It never struck [her]31-bernardine that [she]31-bernardine was selfish . [One]958-one does not think of that until the great check comes . [One]958-one goes on , and would go on . But a barrier rises up . Then , finding [one]958-one can advance no further , one turns round ; and what does [one]958-one see ? [Bernardine]31-bernardine saw that [she]31-bernardine had come a long journey . [She]31-bernardine saw what [the Traveller]264-the traveller saw . That was all [she]31-bernardine saw at first . Then [she]31-bernardine remembered that [she]31-bernardine had done the journey entirely for [her]31-bernardine own sake . Perhaps it might not have looked so dreary if it had been undertaken for some one else . [She]31-bernardine had claimed nothing of [any one]146-any one ; [she]31-bernardine had given nothing to [any one]146-any one . [She]31-bernardine had simply taken [her]31-bernardine life in [her]31-bernardine own hands and made what [she]31-bernardine could of it . What had [she]31-bernardine made of it ? [Many women]315-many women asked for riches , for position , for influence and authority and admiration . [She]31-bernardine had only asked to be able to work . It seemed little enough to ask . That [she]31-bernardine asked so little placed [her]31-bernardine , so [she]31-bernardine thought , apart from [the common herd of eager askers]316-the common herd of eager askers . To be cut off from active life and earnest work was a possibility which never occurred to [her]31-bernardine . It never crossed [her]31-bernardine mind that in asking for the one thing for which [she]31-bernardine longed , [she]31-bernardine was really asking for the greatest thing . Now , in the hour of [her]31-bernardine enfeeblement , and in the hour of the bitterness of [her]31-bernardine heart , [she]31-bernardine still prided [herself]31-bernardine upon wanting so little . " It seems so little to ask , "[31-bernardine] [she]31-bernardine cried to [herself]31-bernardine time after time . " [I]31-bernardine only want to be able to do a few strokes of work . [I]31-bernardine would be content now to do so little , if only [I]31-bernardine might do some . [The laziest day - labourer]1049-the laziest day - labourer on [the road]181-the road would laugh at the small amount of work which would content [me]31-bernardine now . "[31-bernardine] [She]31-bernardine told [the Disagreeable Man]102-the disagreeable man that one day . " So [you]31-bernardine think [you]31-bernardine are moderate in [your]31-bernardine demands , "[102-the disagreeable man] [he]102-the disagreeable man said to [her]31-bernardine . " [You]31-bernardine are [a most amusing young woman]1051-a most amusing young woman . [You]31-bernardine are so perfectly unconscious how exacting [you]31-bernardine really are . For , after all , what is it [you]31-bernardine want ? [You]31-bernardine want to have that wonderful brain of [yours]31-bernardine restored , so that [you]31-bernardine may begin to teach , and , perhaps , write a book . Well , to repeat [my]102-the disagreeable man former words : [you]31-bernardine are still at phase one , and [you]31-bernardine are longing to be strong enough to fulfil [your]31-bernardine ambitions and write a book . When [you]31-bernardine arrive at phase four , [you]31-bernardine will be quite content to dust one of [[your]31-bernardine uncle]1052-your uncle 's books instead : far more useful work and far more worthy of encouragement . If [every one who wrote books now]1053-every one who wrote books now would be satisfied to dust books already written , what [a regenerated world]1054-a regenerated world [it]1054-a regenerated world would become ! "[102-the disagreeable man] [She]31-bernardine laughed good - temperedly . [His]318-him remarks did not vex [her]31-bernardine ; or , at least , [she]31-bernardine showed no vexation . [He]318-him seemed to have constituted [himself]318-him as [[her]31-bernardine critic]319-her critic , and [she]31-bernardine made no objections . [She]31-bernardine had given [him]318-him little bits of stray confidence about [herself]31-bernardine , and [she]31-bernardine received everything [he]318-him had to say with that kind of forbearance which chivalry bids [us]320-us show to [the weak and ailing]321-the weak and ailing . [She]31-bernardine made allowances for [him]318-him ; but [she]31-bernardine did more than that for [him]318-him : [she]31-bernardine did not let [him]318-him see that [she]31-bernardine made allowances . Moreover , [she]31-bernardine recognized amidst all [his]318-him roughness a certain kind of sympathy which [she]31-bernardine could not resent , because it was not aggressive . For to some natures the expression of sympathy is an irritation ; to be sympathized with means to be pitied , and to be pitied means to be looked down upon . [She]31-bernardine was sorry for [him]318-him , but [she]31-bernardine would not have told [him]318-him so for worlds ; [he]318-him would have shrunk from pity as much as [she]31-bernardine did . And yet the sympathy which [she]31-bernardine thought [she]31-bernardine did not want for [herself]31-bernardine , [she]31-bernardine was silently giving to those around [her]31-bernardine , like [herself]31-bernardine , thwarted , each in a different way perhaps , still thwarted all the same . [She]31-bernardine found more than once that [she]31-bernardine was learning to measure [people]946-people by a standard different from [her]31-bernardine former one ; not by what [they]946-people had done or been , but by what [they]946-people had suffered . But such a change as this does not come suddenly , though , in [a place like [Petershof]2-petershof]323-a place like petershof , it comes quickly , almost unconsciously . The Petershof climate had got into [her]27-mrs. reffold head ; and it is a well - known fact that this glorious air has the effect on [some people]135-some people of banishing from [their]135-some people minds all inconvenient notions of duty and devotion , and all memory of the special object of [their]135-some people sojourn in [Petershof]2-petershof . ' [Mrs. Reffold]27-mrs. reffold was not [the only sinner in this respect]369-the only sinner in this respect . It would have been interesting to get together [a tea - party of [invalids]371-invalids alone , and set the ball rolling about the respective behaviours of [[their]371-invalids respective friends]372-their respective friends]370-a tea - party of invalids alone , and set the ball rolling about the respective behaviours of their respective friends . Not a pleasing chronicle : no very choice pages to add to the book of real life ; still , valuable items in [their]371-invalids way , representative of the actual as opposed to the ideal . In most instances there would have been ample testimony to that cruel monster , known as Neglect . [Bernardine]31-bernardine spoke once to [the Disagreeable Man on this subject]373-the disagreeable man on this subject . [She]31-bernardine spoke with indignation , and [he]373-the disagreeable man on this subject answered with indifference , shrugging [his]373-the disagreeable man on this subject shoulders . " These things occur , "[373-the disagreeable man on this subject] [he]373-the disagreeable man on this subject said " It is not that they are worse here than everywhere else ; it is simply that they are together in an accumulated mass , and , as such , strike [us]1087-us with tremendous force . [I]31-bernardine [myself]31-bernardine am accustomed to these exhibitions of selfishness and neglect . [I]31-bernardine should be astonished if they did not take place . Do n't mix [yourself]1088-you up with anything . If [people]946-people are neglected , [they]946-people are neglected , and there is the end of it . To imagine that [you]1088-you or [I]31-bernardine are going to do any good by filling up the breach , is simply an insanity leading to unnecessarily disagreeable consequences . [I]31-bernardine know [you]1088-you go to see [Mr. Reffold]48-mr. reffold . Take [my]31-bernardine advice , and keep away . "[31-bernardine] " [[My]374-he dear young woman]1091-my dear young woman , "[374-he] [he]374-he said , " [we]1092-we are not living in a poetry book bound with gilt edges . [We]1092-we are living in a paper - backed volume of prose . Be sensible . Do n't ruffle [yourself]1088-you on account of [other people]150-other people . Do n't even trouble to criticize [them]150-other people ; it is only a nuisance to [yourself]1088-you . All this simply points back to [my]374-he first suggestion : fill up [your]1088-you time with some hobby , cheese - mites or the influenza bacillus , and then [you]1088-you will be quite content to let [people]946-people be neglected , lonely , and to die . [You]1088-you will look upon it as an ordinary and natural process . "[374-he] [She]31-bernardine waved [her]31-bernardine hand as though to stop [him]374-he . " There are days , "[31-bernardine] [she]31-bernardine said , " when [I]31-bernardine ca n't bear to talk with [you]374-he . And this is one of them . "[31-bernardine] " [I]374-he am sorry , "[374-he] [he]374-he answered , quite gently for [him]374-he . And [he]374-he moved away from [her]31-bernardine , and started for [his]374-he usual lonely walk . [Bernardine]31-bernardine turned [home]119-home , intending to go to see [Mr. Reffold]48-mr. reffold . [He]374-he had become quite attached to [her]31-bernardine , and looked forward eagerly to [her]31-bernardine visits . [He]374-he said [her]31-bernardine voice was gentle and [her]31-bernardine manner quiet ; there was no bustling vitality about [her]31-bernardine to irritate [his]374-he worn nerves . [He]374-he was probably [an empty - headed , stupid fellow]376-an empty - headed , stupid fellow ; but it was none the less sad to see [him]374-he passing away . [He]374-he called [her]31-bernardine ' [Little Brick]53-little brick . ' [He]374-he said that no other epithet suited [her]31-bernardine so exactly . [He]374-he was quite satisfied now that [she]31-bernardine was not paid for coming to see [him]374-he . As for the reading , [no one]157-no one could read the Sporting and Dramatic News and the Era so well as [Little Brick]53-little brick . Sometimes [he]374-he spoke with [her]31-bernardine about [[his]374-he wife]120-his wife , but only in general terms of bitterness , and not always complainingly . [She]31-bernardine listened and said nothing . " [I]374-he 'm [a chap that wants very little]1095-a chap that wants very little , "[374-he] [he]374-he said once . " [Those who want little]1096-those who want little , get nothing . "[374-he] That was all [he]374-he said , but [Bernardine]31-bernardine knew to whom [he]374-he referred . To - day , as [Bernardine]31-bernardine was on [her]31-bernardine way back to [the Kurhaus]7-the kurhaus , [she]31-bernardine was thinking constantly of [Mrs. Reffold]27-mrs. reffold , and wondering whether [she]31-bernardine ought to be made to realize that [[her]31-bernardine husband]379-her husband was becoming rapidly worse . Whilst engrossed with this thought , [a long train of sledges]380-a long train of sledges and toboggans passed [her]31-bernardine . The sound of the bells and the noisy merriment made [her]31-bernardine look up , and [she]31-bernardine saw [beautiful Mrs. Reffold]27-mrs. reffold amongst [the pleasure - seekers]381-the pleasure - seekers . " If only [I]31-bernardine dared tell [her]27-mrs. reffold now , "[31-bernardine] said [Bernardine]31-bernardine to [herself]31-bernardine , " loudly and before [them]381-the pleasure - seekers all ! "[31-bernardine] Then a more sensible mood came over [her]31-bernardine . " After all , it is not [my]31-bernardine affair , "[31-bernardine] [she]31-bernardine said . And the sledges passed away out of hearing . When [Bernardine]31-bernardine sat with [Mr. Reffold]48-mr. reffold that afternoon [she]31-bernardine did not mention that [she]31-bernardine had seen [[his]48-mr. reffold wife]120-his wife . [He]48-mr. reffold coughed a great deal , and seemed to be worse than usual , and complained of fever . But [he]48-mr. reffold liked to have [her]120-his wife , and would not hear of [her]120-his wife going . " Stay , "[48-mr. reffold] [he]48-mr. reffold said . " It is not much of a pleasure to [you]31-bernardine , but it is a great pleasure to [me]48-mr. reffold . "[48-mr. reffold] There was an anxious look on [his]48-mr. reffold face , such a look as [people]946-people wear when [they]946-people wish to ask some question of great moment , but dare not begin . At last [he]48-mr. reffold seemed to summon up courage . " [Little Brick]53-little brick , "[48-mr. reffold] [he]48-mr. reffold said , in a weak low voice , " [I]48-mr. reffold have something on [my]48-mr. reffold mind . [You]53-little brick wo n't laugh , [I]48-mr. reffold know . [You]53-little brick 're not the sort . " Well , "[31-bernardine] [she]31-bernardine said kindly , " tell [me]31-bernardine . "[31-bernardine] " [You]53-little brick must have thought a good deal , [I]384-i suppose , "[384-i] [he]384-i continued , " about life and death , and that sort of thing . [I]31-bernardine 've never thought at all . Does it matter , [Little Brick]53-little brick ? It 's too late now . [I]31-bernardine ca n't begin to think . But speak to [me]31-bernardine ; tell [me]31-bernardine what [you]53-little brick think . Do [you]53-little brick believe [we]1099-we get another chance , and are glad to behave less like [curs]1100-curs and [brutes]1101-brutes ? Or is it all ended in [that lonely little churchyard here]1102-that lonely little churchyard here ? [I]31-bernardine 've never troubled about these things before , but now [I]31-bernardine know [I]31-bernardine am so near [that gloomy little churchyard]1103-that gloomy little churchyard — well , it makes [me]31-bernardine wonder . As for the Bible , [I]31-bernardine never cared to read it , [I]31-bernardine was never much of [a reader]1104-a reader , though [I]31-bernardine 've got through two or three firework novels and sporting stories . Does it matter , [Little Brick]53-little brick ? "[31-bernardine] " How do [I]385-i know ? "[385-i] [she]385-i said gently . " How does [any one]146-any one know ? [People]946-people have gone mad over [their]946-people guessing , or [they]946-people have broken [their]946-people hearts . But still the mystery remains , and [we]1099-we can not solve it . "[385-i] " If [you]385-i do n't know anything , [Little Brick]53-little brick , "[386-you] [he]386-you said , " at least tell [me]386-you what [you]385-i think : and do n't be too learned ; remember [I]386-you 'm only [a brainless fellow]1108-a brainless fellow . "[386-you] [He]386-you seemed to be waiting eagerly for [her]385-i answer . " If [I]385-i were [you]386-you , "[385-i] [she]385-i said , " [I]385-i should not worry . Just make up [your]386-you mind to do better when [you]386-you get another chance . One ca n't do more than that . That is what [I]385-i shall think of : that [God]44-god will give each one of [us]1099-we another chance , and that each one of [us]1099-we will take it and do better — [I]385-i and [you]386-you and [every one]231-every one . So there is no need to fret over failure , when one hopes [one]958-one may be allowed to redeem that failure later on . Besides which , life is very hard . Why , [we]1099-we [ourselves]1099-we recognize that . If there be [a God]1111-a god , [some Intelligence greater than human intelligence]1112-some intelligence greater than human intelligence , [he]1111-a god will understand better than [ourselves]1099-we that life is very hard and difficult , and [he]1111-a god will be astonished not because [we]1099-we are not better , but because [we]1099-we are not worse . "[388-you] ONE specially fine morning a knock came at [Bernardine]31-bernardine 's door . [She]31-bernardine opened it , and found [Robert Allitsen]40-robert allitsen standing there , trying to recover [his]40-robert allitsen breath . " [I]40-robert allitsen am going to [Loschwitz]11-loschwitz , [a village about twelve miles off]1118-a village about twelve miles off , "[40-robert allitsen] [he]40-robert allitsen said . " And [I]40-robert allitsen have ordered a sledge . Do [you]388-you care to come too ? "[40-robert allitsen] " If [I]31-bernardine may pay [my]31-bernardine share , "[31-bernardine] [she]31-bernardine said . " Of course , "[40-robert allitsen] [he]40-robert allitsen answered ; " [I]40-robert allitsen did not suppose [you]388-you would like to be paid for any better than [I]40-robert allitsen should like to pay for [you]388-you . "[40-robert allitsen] [Bernardine]31-bernardine laughed . " When do [we]1119-we start ? "[31-bernardine] [she]31-bernardine asked . " Now , "[40-robert allitsen] [he]40-robert allitsen answered . " Bring a rug , and also that shawl of yours which is always falling down , and come at once without any fuss . [We]1119-we shall be out for the whole day . What about [Mrs. Grundy]54-mrs. grundy ? [We]1119-we could manage to take [her]54-mrs. grundy if [you]388-you wished , but [she]54-mrs. grundy would not be comfortable sitting amongst the photographic apparatus , and [I]40-robert allitsen certainly should not give up [my]40-robert allitsen seat to [her]54-mrs. grundy . "[40-robert allitsen] " Then leave [her]54-mrs. grundy at [home]119-home , "[31-bernardine] said [Bernardine]31-bernardine cheerily . And so [they]390-they settled it . In less than a quarter of an hour [they]390-they had started ; and [Bernardine]31-bernardine leaned luxuriously back to enjoy to the full [her]31-bernardine first sledge - drive . It was all new to [her]31-bernardine : the swift passing through the crisp air without any sensation of motion ; the sleepy tinkling of the bells on the horses ' heads ; the noiseless cutting through of the snow - path . All these weeks [she]31-bernardine had known nothing of [the country]391-the country , and now [she]31-bernardine found [herself]31-bernardine in [the snow fairy - land of which [the Disagreeable Man]102-the disagreeable man had often spoken to [her]31-bernardine]392-the snow fairy - land of which the disagreeable man had often spoken to her . Around , [vast plains of untouched snow]394-vast plains of untouched snow , whiter than any dream of whiteness , jewelled by the sunshine with priceless diamonds , numberless as [the sands of [the sea]396-the sea]395-the sands of the sea . The great pines bearing [their]397-their burden of snow patiently ; others , less patient , having shaken [themselves]398-themselves free from what the heavens had sent [them]398-themselves to bear . And now the streams , flowing on reluctantly over ice - coated rocks , and the ice cathedrals formed by the icicles between the rocks . And always the same silence , save for the tinkling of the horses ' bells . On the heights [the quaint chalets]399-the quaint chalets , [some merely huts for storing wood]400-some merely huts for storing wood ; on [others]939-others , [farms]402-farms , or [the homes of [peasants]404-peasants]403-the homes of peasants ; some dark brown , almost black , betraying [their]405-their age ; others of a paler hue , showing that the sun had not yet mellowed [them]405-their into a deep rich colour . And on all alike , the fringe of icicles . [A wonderful white world]406-a wonderful white world . It was a long time before [Bernardine]31-bernardine even wished to speak . This beautiful whiteness may become monotonous after a time , but there is something very awe - inspiring about it , something which catches the soul and holds it . [The Disagreeable Man]28-the disagreeable man sat quietly by [her]31-bernardine side . Once or twice [he]28-the disagreeable man bent forward to protect the camera when [the sledge]407-the sledge gave a lurch . After some time [they]408-they met a procession of sledges laden with timber ; and [August]55-august , [the driver]409-the driver , and [Robert Allitsen]40-robert allitsen exchanged some fun and merriment with [the drivers]410-the drivers in [[their]410-the drivers quaint blue smocks]411-their quaint blue smocks . The noise of the conversation , and the excitement of getting past the sledges , brought [Bernardine]31-bernardine back to speech again . " [I]31-bernardine have never before enjoyed anything so much , "[31-bernardine] [she]31-bernardine said . " So [you]31-bernardine have found [your]31-bernardine tongue , "[28-the disagreeable man] [he]28-the disagreeable man said . " Do [you]31-bernardine mind talking a little now ? [I]28-the disagreeable man feel rather lonely . "[28-the disagreeable man] This was said in such a pathetic , aggrieved tone , that [Bernardine]31-bernardine laughed and looked at [[her]31-bernardine companion]412-her companion . [His]28-the disagreeable man face wore an unusually bright expression . [He]28-the disagreeable man was evidently out to enjoy [himself]28-the disagreeable man . " [You]28-the disagreeable man talk , "[31-bernardine] [she]31-bernardine said ; " and tell [me]31-bernardine all about [the country]391-the country . [He]28-the disagreeable man was able to point out where some had fallen the previous year . "[28-the disagreeable man] " What a confession for [you]28-the disagreeable man to make of [any one]146-any one ! "[31-bernardine] said [she]31-bernardine . The time passed away pleasantly . [The Disagreeable Man]102-the disagreeable man was scarcely [himself]102-the disagreeable man to - day ; or was it that [he]102-the disagreeable man was more like [himself]102-the disagreeable man ? [He]102-the disagreeable man seemed in a boyish mood ; [he]102-the disagreeable man made fun out of nothing , and laughed with such young fresh laughter , that even [August]55-august , [the grave blue - spectacled driver]415-the grave blue - spectacled driver , was moved to mirth . As for [Bernardine]31-bernardine , [she]31-bernardine had to look at [Robert Allitsen]40-robert allitsen several times to be sure that [he]40-robert allitsen was [the same [Robert Allitsen]40-robert allitsen [she]31-bernardine had known two hours ago in [Petershof]2-petershof]416-the same robert allitsen she had known two hours ago in petershof . [No one]157-no one could be a cheerier companion than [herself]31-bernardine when [she]31-bernardine chose . At last [they]418-they arrived at [Loschwitz]11-loschwitz . [The sledge]407-the sledge wound its way through [the sloshy streets of [the queer little village]421-the queer little village]420-the sloshy streets of the queer little village , and finally drew up in front of [the Gasthaus]13-the gasthaus . [It]422-it was [a black sunburnt châlet , with green shutters , and steps]423-a black sunburnt châlet , with green shutters , and steps leading up to [a green balcony]424-a green balcony . A fringe of sausages hung from the roof ; red bedding was scorching in the sunshine ; three cats were sunning themselves on the steps ; [a young woman]425-a young woman sat in the green balcony knitting . There were some curious inscriptions on the walls of [the châlet]426-the châlet , and the date was distinctly marked , " 1670 . "[427-an old woman over the way] [An old woman over the way]427-an old woman over the way sat in [her]427-an old woman over the way doorway spinning . [She]427-an old woman over the way looked up as [the sledge]407-the sledge stopped before [the Gasthaus]13-the gasthaus ; but [the young woman in the green balcony]429-the young woman in the green balcony went on knitting , and saw nothing . [A buxom elderly Hausfrau]430-a buxom elderly hausfrau , came out to greet [the guests]325-the guests . [She]427-an old woman over the way wore a naturally kind expression on [her]427-an old woman over the way old face , but when [she]427-an old woman over the way saw who [the gentleman]432-the gentleman was , the kindness positive increased to kindness superlative . [She]427-an old woman over the way first retired and called out : " [Liza]56-liza , [Fritz]57-fritz , [Liza]56-liza , Trüdchen , come quickly ! "[427-an old woman over the way] Then [she]427-an old woman over the way came back , and cried : " [Herr Allitsen]58-herr allitsen , what a surprise ! "[427-an old woman over the way] [She]427-an old woman over the way shook [his]432-the gentleman hand times without number , greeted [Bernardine]31-bernardine with motherly tenderness , and interspersed all [her]427-an old woman over the way remarks with frantic cries of " [Liza]56-liza , [Fritz]57-fritz , Trüdchen , make haste ! "[427-an old woman over the way] [She]427-an old woman over the way became very hot and excited , and gesticulated violently . All this time [the young woman]133-the young woman sat knitting , but not looking up . [She]133-the young woman had been beautiful , but [her]133-the young woman face was worn now , and [her]133-the young woman eyes had that vacant stare which betokened the vacant mind . [The mother]434-the mother whispered to [Robert Allitsen]40-robert allitsen : " [She]133-the young woman notices [no one]157-no one now ; [she]133-the young woman sits there always waiting . "[434-the mother] Tears came into the kind old eyes . [Robert Allitsen]40-robert allitsen went and bent down to [the young woman]133-the young woman , and held out [his]40-robert allitsen hand . " [Catharina]59-catharina , "[40-robert allitsen] [he]40-robert allitsen said gently . [She]133-the young woman looked up then , and saw [him]40-robert allitsen , and recognized [him]40-robert allitsen . Then the sad face smiled a welcome . [He]40-robert allitsen sat near [her]133-the young woman , and took [her]133-the young woman knitting in [his]40-robert allitsen hand , pretending to examine what [she]133-the young woman had done , chatting to [her]133-the young woman quietly all the time . [He]40-robert allitsen asked [her]133-the young woman what [she]133-the young woman had been doing with [herself]133-the young woman since [he]40-robert allitsen had last seen [her]133-the young woman , and [she]133-the young woman said : " Waiting . [I]133-the young woman am always waiting . "[133-the young woman] [He]40-robert allitsen knew that [she]133-the young woman referred to [[her]133-the young woman lover , who had been lost in an avalanche the eve before [their]437-their wedding morning]436-her lover , who had been lost in an avalanche the eve before their wedding morning . That was four years ago , but [Catharina]59-catharina was still waiting . [Allitsen]40-robert allitsen remembered [her]59-catharina as [a bright young girl]438-a bright young girl , singing in [the Gasthaus]13-the gasthaus , waiting cheerfully on [the guests]325-the guests : a bright gracious presence . [No one]157-no one could cook trout as [she]133-the young woman could ; many a dish of trout had [she]133-the young woman served up for [him]40-robert allitsen . And now [she]59-catharina sat in the sunshine , knitting and waiting , scarcely ever looking up . That was [her]59-catharina life . " [Catharina]59-catharina , "[40-robert allitsen] [he]40-robert allitsen said , as [he]40-robert allitsen gave [her]59-catharina back [her]59-catharina knitting , " do [you]59-catharina remember how [you]59-catharina used to cook [me]40-robert allitsen the trout ? "[40-robert allitsen] Another smile passed over [her]59-catharina face . Yes , [she]59-catharina remembered . " Will [you]40-robert allitsen cook [me]59-catharina some to - day ? [They]465-they both stood perfectly straight , just as [a soldier]466-a soldier stands before presenting arms . [Both faces]467-both faces were perfectly expressionless . " Well , [I]492-his companion only know , "[492-his companion] [she]492-his companion said cheerily , " that [I]492-his companion have enjoyed [my]492-his companion day very much , and [I]492-his companion 'm much obliged to [you]493-he for [your]493-he companionship . "[493-he] [She]492-his companion followed [him]493-he to [the restaurant]1152-the restaurant , touched by [his]493-he rough kindness . [He]493-he [himself]493-he took nothing , but [he]493-he paid for [her]492-his companion brandy . That evening after table - d'hôte , or rather after [he]493-he had finished [his]493-he dinner , [he]493-he rose to go to [[his]493-he room]244-his room as usual . [He]493-he generally went off without a remark . But to - night [he]493-he said : " Good - night , and thank [you]492-his companion for [your]492-his companion companionship . It has been [my]493-he birthday to - day , and [I]493-he 've quite enjoyed it . "[493-he] THERE was a suicide in [the Kurhaus]7-the kurhaus one afternoon . [A Dutchman]497-a dutchman , [Vandervelt]69-vandervelt , had received rather a bad account of [himself]69-vandervelt from [the doctor]498-the doctor a few days previously , and in a fit of depression , so it was thought , [he]69-vandervelt had put a bullet through [his]69-vandervelt head . It had occurred through [Marie]39-marie 's unconscious agency . [She]39-marie found [him]69-vandervelt lying on [his]69-vandervelt sofa when [she]39-marie went as usual to take [him]69-vandervelt [his]69-vandervelt afternoon glass of milk . [He]69-vandervelt asked [her]39-marie to give [him]69-vandervelt a packet which was on the top shelf of [his]69-vandervelt cupboard . " Willingly , "[39-marie] [she]39-marie said , and [she]39-marie jumped nimbly on the chair , and gave [him]69-vandervelt the case . " Anything more ? "[39-marie] [she]39-marie asked kindly , as [she]39-marie watched [him]69-vandervelt draw [himself]69-vandervelt up from the sofa . [She]39-marie thought at the time that [he]69-vandervelt looked wild and strange ; but then , as [she]39-marie pathetically said afterwards , who did not look wild and strange in [the Kurhaus]7-the kurhaus ? " Yes , "[69-vandervelt] [he]69-vandervelt said . " Here are five francs for [you]39-marie . "[69-vandervelt] [She]39-marie thought that rather unusual too ; but five francs , especially coming unexpectedly like that , were not to be despised , and [Marie]39-marie determined to send [them]499-them off to that [Mutterli]68-mutterli at [home]119-home in [the nut - brown châlet]501-the nut - brown châlet at [Grüsch]16-grüsch . So [she]39-marie thanked [Mynheer van Vandervelt]69-vandervelt , and went off to [[her]39-marie pantry]195-her pantry to drink some cold tea which [the English people]503-the english people had left , and to clean the lamps . Having done that , and knowing that [the matron]504-the matron was busily engaged carrying on a flirtation with [a young Frenchman]505-a young frenchman , [Marie]39-marie took out [her]39-marie writing materials , and began a letter to [[her]39-marie old mother]506-her old mother . [These peasants]507-these peasants know how to love [each other]167-each other , and [some of [them]507-these peasants]509-some of them know how to tell [each other]167-each other too . [Marie]39-marie knew . And [she]39-marie told [[her]39-marie mother]452-her mother of the gifts [she]39-marie was bringing [home]119-home , the little nothings given [her]39-marie by [the guests]325-the guests . [She]39-marie was very happy writing this letter : [the little nut - brown home]514-the little nut - brown home rose before [her]39-marie . " Ach ! "[39-marie] [she]39-marie said , " how [I]39-marie long to be [home]119-home ! "[39-marie] And then [she]39-marie put down [her]39-marie pen , and sighed . " Ach ! "[39-marie] [she]39-marie said , " and when [I]39-marie 'm [there]141-there , [I]39-marie shall long to be [here]943-here . Da wo ich nicht bin , da ist [das Gluck]17-das gluck . "[39-marie] [Marie]39-marie was something of [a philosopher]515-a philosopher . Suddenly [she]39-marie heard the report of a pistol , followed by a second report . [She]39-marie dashed out of [[her]39-marie little pantry]516-her little pantry , and ran in the direction of the sound . [She]39-marie saw [Wäli]37-wäli in [the passage]517-the passage . [He]37-wäli was looking scared , and [his]37-wäli letters had fallen to the ground . [He]37-wäli pointed to [No . 54]518-no . 54 . It was [[the Dutchman]519-the dutchman 's room]520-the dutchman 's room . [Help]70-help arrived . The door was forced open , and [Vandervelt]69-vandervelt was found dead . The case from which [he]37-wäli had taken the pistol was lying on the sofa . When [Marie]39-marie saw that , [she]39-marie knew that [she]39-marie had been [an unconscious accomplice]521-an unconscious accomplice . [Her]39-marie tender heart overflowed with grief . [Whilst others]522-whilst others were lifting [him]37-wäli up , [she]39-marie leaned [her]39-marie head against the wall , and sobbed . " It was [my]39-marie fault , it was [my]39-marie fault ! "[39-marie] [she]39-marie cried . " [I]39-marie gave [him]37-wäli the case . But how was [I]39-marie to know ? "[39-marie] [They]523-they took [her]39-marie away , and tried to comfort [her]39-marie , but it was all in vain . " And [he]37-wäli gave [me]39-marie five francs , "[39-marie] [she]39-marie sobbed . " [I]39-marie shudder to think of [them]1156-them . "[39-marie] It was all in vain that [Wäli]37-wäli gave [her]39-marie a letter for which [she]39-marie had been longing for many days . " It is from [[your]39-marie Mutterli]1157-your mutterli , "[37-wäli] [he]37-wäli said , as [he]37-wäli put it into [her]39-marie hands . " [I]37-wäli give it willingly . "[37-wäli] But nothing could cheer [her]39-marie . [Wäli]37-wäli went away shaking [his]37-wäli curly head sadly , shocked at the death of [the Dutchman]519-the dutchman , and shocked at [Marie]39-marie 's sorrow . And [the cheery little postman]525-the cheery little postman did not do much whistling that evening . [Bernardine]31-bernardine heard of [Marie]39-marie 's trouble , and rang for [her]39-marie to come . [Marie]39-marie answered the bell , looking the picture of misery . [Her]39-marie kind face was tear - stained , and [her]39-marie only voice was a sob . [Bernardine]31-bernardine drew [the girl]479-the girl to [her]39-marie . " [Poor old Marie]39-marie , "[31-bernardine] [she]31-bernardine whispered . " Come and cry [your]39-marie kind heart out , and then [you]39-marie will feel better . Sit by [me]31-bernardine here , and do n't try to speak . And [I]31-bernardine will make [you]39-marie some tea in true English fashion , and [you]39-marie must take it hot , and it will do [you]39-marie good . "[31-bernardine] The simple sisterly kindness and silent sympathy soothed [Marie]39-marie after a time . The sobs ceased , and the tears also . [They]1158-they would bring [her]1159-my old mother ill luck — indeed [they]1158-they would . "[39-marie] The matter was solved by [Bernardine]31-bernardine in a masterly fashion . This idea comforted [Marie]39-marie beyond [Bernardine]31-bernardine 's most sanguine expectations . " A beautiful tin wreath , "[39-marie] [she]39-marie said several times . " [I]39-marie know the exact kind . When [[my]39-marie father]1160-my father died , [we]1161-we put one on [his]1160-my father grave . "[39-marie] That same evening , during table - d'hôte , [Bernardine]31-bernardine told [the Disagreeable Man]102-the disagreeable man the history of the afternoon . [He]102-the disagreeable man had been developing photographs , and had heard nothing . [He]102-the disagreeable man seemed very little interested in [her]31-bernardine relation of the suicide , and merely remarked : " Well , there 's one person less in [the world]203-the world . "[102-the disagreeable man] " [I]31-bernardine think [you]102-the disagreeable man make these remarks from habit , "[31-bernardine] [Bernardine]31-bernardine said quietly , and [she]31-bernardine went on with [her]31-bernardine dinner , attempting no further conversation with [him]102-the disagreeable man . [She]31-bernardine [herself]31-bernardine had been much moved by the sad occurrence ; [every one in [the Kurhaus]7-the kurhaus]528-every one in the kurhaus was more or less upset ; and there was a thoughtful , anxious expression on more than one ordinarily thoughtless face . [The little French danseuse]529-the little french danseuse was quiet : [the Portuguese ladies]196-the portuguese ladies were decidedly tearful , [the vulgar German Baroness]74-the vulgar german baroness was quite depressed : [the comedian at the Belgian table]531-the comedian at the belgian table ate [his]531-the comedian at the belgian table dinner in silence . In fact , there was a weight pressing down on all . Was it really possible , thought [Bernardine]31-bernardine , that [Robert Allitsen]40-robert allitsen was [the only one there unconcerned and unmoved]532-the only one there unconcerned and unmoved ? [She]31-bernardine had seen [him]40-robert allitsen in a different light amongst [[his]40-robert allitsen friends]489-his friends , [the country folk]534-the country folk , but it was just a glimpse which had not lasted long . The young- heartedness , the geniality , the sympathy which had so astonished [her]31-bernardine during [their]535-their day 's outing , astonished [her]31-bernardine still more by [their]535-their total disappearance . The gruffness had returned : or had it never been absent ? The lovelessness and leadenness of [his]40-robert allitsen temperament had once more asserted [themselves]535-their : or was it that [they]535-their had never for one single day been in the background ? These thoughts passed through [her]31-bernardine mind as [he]40-robert allitsen sat next to [her]31-bernardine reading [his]40-robert allitsen paper — that paper which [he]40-robert allitsen never passed on to any one . [She]31-bernardine hardened [her]31-bernardine heart against [him]40-robert allitsen ; there was no need for ill - health and disappointment to have brought [any one]146-any one to a miserable state of indifference like that . Then [she]31-bernardine looked at [his]40-robert allitsen wan face and frail form , and [her]31-bernardine heart softened at once . At the moment when [her]31-bernardine heart softened to [him]40-robert allitsen , [he]40-robert allitsen astonished [her]31-bernardine by handing [her]31-bernardine [his]40-robert allitsen paper . " Here is something to interest [you]31-bernardine , "[40-robert allitsen] [he]40-robert allitsen said , " an article on Realism in Fiction , or some nonsense like that . '' "[40-robert allitsen] [I]0-i thought [you]40-robert allitsen never lent anything , " [she]31-bernardine said , as [she]31-bernardine glanced at the article , "[40-robert allitsen] much less gave it . " "[40-robert allitsen] Giving and lending are not usually in [my]0-i line , " [he]40-robert allitsen replied . "[0-i] [I]0-i think [I]0-i told [you]31-bernardine once that [I]0-i thought selfishness perfectly desirable and legitimate , if [one]958-one had made the one great sacrifice . " "[0-i] Yes , " [she]31-bernardine said eagerly , "[0-i] [I]0-i have often wondered what [you]40-robert allitsen considered the one great sacrifice . " "[40-robert allitsen] Come out into the air , " [he]40-robert allitsen answered , "[40-robert allitsen] and [I]0-i will tell [you]31-bernardine . " [She]31-bernardine went to put on [her]31-bernardine cloak and , hat , and found [him]40-robert allitsen waiting for [her]31-bernardine at the top of [the staircase]1163-the staircase . [They]1164-they passed out into the beautiful night : the sky was radiantly bejewelled , the air crisp and cold , and harmless to do ill . In the distance , the jodelling of [some peasants]1165-some peasants . In [the hotels]1166-the hotels , the fun and merriment , side by side with the suffering and hopelessness . In [[the deaconess]1167-the deaconess 's house]1168-the deaconess 's house , the body of [the Dutchman]519-the dutchman . In [[God]44-god 's heavens]1170-god 's heavens , [God]44-god 's stars . [Robert Allitsen]40-robert allitsen and [Bernardine]31-bernardine walked silently for some time . "[0-i] Well , " [she]0-i said , "[0-i] now tell [me]0-i . " "[0-i] The one great sacrifice , " [he]40-robert allitsen said half to [himself]40-robert allitsen , "[0-i] is the going on living [one]958-one 's life for the sake of another , when everything that would seem to make life acceptable has been wrenched away , not the pleasures , but the duties , and the possibilities of expressing [one]958-one 's energies , either in one direction or another : when , in fact , living is only a long tedious dying . If [one]958-one has made this sacrifice , everything else may be forgiven . " [He]40-robert allitsen paused a moment , and then continued : "[0-i] [I]0-i have made this sacrifice , therefore [I]0-i consider [I]0-i have done [my]0-i part without flinching . The greatest thing [I]0-i had to give up , [I]0-i gave up : [my]0-i death . More could not be required of [any one]146-any one ! " [He]40-robert allitsen paused again , and [Bernardine]31-bernardine was silent from mere awe . "[0-i] But freedom comes at last , " [he]40-robert allitsen said , "[0-i] and some day [I]0-i shall be free . When [[my]0-i mother]542-my mother dies , [I]0-i shall be free . [She]542-my mother is old . If [I]0-i were to die , [I]0-i should break [her]542-my mother heart , or , rather [she]542-my mother would fancy that [her]542-my mother heart was broken . ( And it comes to the same thing ) . And [I]0-i should not like to give [her]542-my mother more grief than [she]542-my mother has had . So [I]0-i am just waiting , it may be months , or weeks , or years . But [I]0-i know how to wait : if [I]0-i have not learnt anything else , [I]0-i have learnt how to wait . And then " . . . . [Bernardine]31-bernardine had unconsciously put [her]31-bernardine hand on [his]544-your dutchman arm ; [her]31-bernardine face was full of suffering . "[73-the dutchman] And then ? " [she]31-bernardine asked , with almost painful eagerness . [THE Dutchman]519-the dutchman was buried in [the little cemetery which faced [the hospital]1173-the hospital]1172-the little cemetery which faced the hospital . [The Kurhaus guests]222-the kurhaus guests recovered from [their]222-the kurhaus guests depression : [the German Baroness]1175-the german baroness returned to [her]1175-the german baroness buoyant vulgarity , [the little danseuse]337-the little danseuse to [her]337-the little danseuse busy flirtations . [The French Marchioness]1177-the french marchioness , celebrated in [Parisian circles]1178-parisian circles for [her]1177-the french marchioness domestic virtues , from which [she]1177-the french marchioness was now taking a holiday , and a very considerable holiday too , gathered [her]1177-the french marchioness nerves together again and took renewed pleasure in the society of [the Russian gentleman]1179-the russian gentleman . [The French Marchioness]1177-the french marchioness had already been requested to leave [three other hotels in [Petershof]2-petershof]1181-three other hotels in petershof ; but it was not at all probable that [the proprietors of the Kurhaus]1182-the proprietors of the kurhaus would have presumed to measure [Madame]75-madame 's morality or immorality . [The Kurhaus committee]1183-the kurhaus committee had a benign indulgence for humanity — provided of course that humanity had a purse — an indulgence which [some of [the English hotels]1185-the english hotels]1184-some of the english hotels would not have done badly to imitate . There was a story afloat concerning [the English quarter]1186-the english quarter , that [a tired little English lady , of no importance to look at]1187-a tired little english lady , of no importance to look at , probably not rich , and probably not handsome , came to [the most respectable hotel in [Petershof]2-petershof]1188-the most respectable hotel in petershof , thinking to find there the peace and quiet which [her]1187-a tired little english lady , of no importance to look at weariness required .
